bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, April 20, 1950

div1.p: Siler describes his preparations to have the plaque memorializing Reed's death unveiled. He has not heard from Wallach and does not know the present status of the bill and the allocation of the funding. He offers his opinion on how any government funding should be spent.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, April 20, 1950
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
----
GORGAS MEMORIAL LABORATORY
JOSEPH F. SILER
PRESIDENT
MAURICE H. THATCHER
VICE PRESIDENT AND GENERAL COUNSEL
WALTER A. BLOEDORN
SECRETARY
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6. D. C.
April 20, 1950.
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p: Many thanks for your note of April 17.

Referring first to your inquiry concerning the Walter Reed plaque to be
placed in front of the building at Fort Leslie McNair, I am very happy to be
able to tell you that the manufacturer of the plaque called me up earlier this
week and said that it had been completed. I went down immediately to inspect
it and think it will be very satisfactory. The next day I went to Fort McNair
and talked with the Commanding Officer concerning the placing of the plaque in
the selected location. He called in the Post Engineer and we went to inspect
the site and decided on just about what should be done. We felt it would be
better to place it on an incline in front of the building in such position as
could easily be seen by people passing by on the sidewalk as well as from
automobiles passing along the street. We felt, too, that the base should be
of concrete and that metal uprights should be installed behind the plaque itself
and be of such length as to permit their being inserted well underneath the
surface of the cement base. I then got in touch with Mr. Cavanagh of the Seal
Company who are making the plaque and, knowing that you expected to be here next
week, I requested that he make every effort to complete the installation of the
plaque this week. He said at first that he might not be able to finish the work
before the first of the month but after I talked with him he agreed to make every
effort to have it finished at an earlier date and said he would let me know as
soon as he learned anything definite from the manufacturing side of their company.

Referring to your comments concerning Mr. Wallach, I have not seen or heard
from him for some time. As I have written you previously, I think that his com-
pany is interested solely in getting out publicity and it was my understanding
that it was their intention to spend the entire $350,000 for publicity purposes,
$150,00 the first year, $100,00 the second and $100,00 the third. As I also
have written you previously, it would seem to me that Walter Reed's memory could
be honored in much more satisfactory and profitable manner by devoting any sum
of this amount to research rather than publicity. The expenditure of $350,00
at the present time for publicity alone seems to me very unwise, particularly
so in view of the deficits our government is incurring every year.

When I talked with Mr. Wallach during his visit here I told him that you
could give him better advice than anyone in this country concerning this matter.
He has not gotten in touch with me since his first visit and I am sorry to say
that I do not know the present status of the bill introduced by Senator Jenner
and Representative Bland. I will endeavor to find out something about it before
you arrive in Washington.

We so far have not given any consideration to having any formal exercises
at the time of the installing of the plaque but as it appears that it will be
impossible to have it installed prior to your visit, we can take the matter up
after your arrival here.

I am looking forward with much pleasure to hearing your talk the latter
part of the month.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, J. F. Siler jfs k
